transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Good morning, how are you feeling today?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I'm doing better, but I still have some neck and back pain after my car accident.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Did you receive any treatment?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes, I had ten physiotherapy sessions and took painkillers.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: What brings you in today?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I still feel anxious while driving after my accident, even though the pain has reduced.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Have you noticed any physical symptoms?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No major pain, but the anxiety worries me.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Good morning, Ms. Jones. How are you feeling today?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Good morning, doctor. I'm doing better, but I still have some discomfort now and then.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: I understand you were in a car accident last September. Can you walk me through what happened?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes, it was on September 1st, around 12:30 in the afternoon. I was driving from Cheadle Hulme to Manchester when I had to stop in traffic. Another car hit me from behind and pushed my car into the one in front.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: That sounds like a strong impact. Were you wearing your seatbelt?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes, I always wear my seatbelt.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: What did you feel immediately after the accident?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: At first I was shocked, but then I realized I had hit my head on the steering wheel and felt pain in my neck and back.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Did you seek medical attention at that time?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes, I went to Moss Bank Accident and Emergency. They told me it was a whiplash injury and sent me home with advice.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: How did things progress after that?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: The first four weeks were very painful. I had trouble sleeping and needed painkillers. Later, I went through ten physiotherapy sessions, which helped.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Are you still experiencing pain now?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: It's not constant. I get occasional backaches, but it's much better than before.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Have you noticed any anxiety while driving or difficulty concentrating?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No, I don't feel anxious while driving and haven't noticed emotional issues.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: How has this affected your daily life and work?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I took a week off work but returned to my usual routine afterward.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: I'll do a quick physical examination now.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Your neck and back show a full range of movement with no tenderness. Everything looks good.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: That's a relief.

transcript.speaker: Physician
transcript.text: Based on your recovery, I expect a full recovery within six months.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate it.
